column2: a free trade deal being negotiated by the United States and the European Union
column3: had essentially failed.""The negotiations with the USA have de facto failed because we Europeans did not want to subject ourselves to American demands

column2: including agriculture.

column7: New York

WASHINGTON Democrat Hillary Clinton called on Friday for voters to reject the ""bigotry"" of Donald Trump's White House campaign
column2: releasing a television ad criticizing his efforts to appeal to black voters and saying she was reaching out to people from all parties who are troubled by his candidacy.The ad shows video of Trump's controversial pitch to black voters

column13: far greater ... than anyone understands. They want to see jobs come in

column19: followed up on Thursday's tough speech by saying that Trump's temperament and divisiveness made him unfit for the White House.

column1: I am reaching out to everyone

column5: everyone who is as troubled as I am by the bigotry and divisiveness of Donald Trump's campaign

Her campaign says no donors received any special favors.Republican National Committee spokesman Sean Spicer told MSNBC Clinton was only talking about Trump and race this week to deflect attention from that controversy.

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN11128U	Clinton leads Trump by 5 points in Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton leads her Republican rival Donald Trump by 5 percentage points among likely voters
column2: down from a peak this month of 12 points
column3: according to the Reuters/Ipsos daily tracking poll released on Friday.DON'T MISS:Not enough money for a 'real' coffins in VenezuelaCarl Icahn says he didn't sell Herbalife shares Burkini controversy goes on in France

column1: The Aug. 22-25 opinion poll found that 41 percent of likely voters supported Clinton ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election
column2: while 36 percent supported Trump. Some 23 percent would not pick either candidate and answered ""refused
column3: ""other"" or ""wouldn't vote.""Clinton
column4: a former secretary of state
column5: has led real estate developer Trump in the poll since Democrats and Republicans ended their national conventions and formally nominated their presidential candidates in July. Her level of support has varied between 41 and 45 percent during that period
column6: and her lead over Trump in the tracking poll peaked this month at 12 percentage points on Tuesday.During the past week
column7: Clinton has been dogged by accusations by Trump
column9: that donations to her family's charitable foundation influenced her actions while she was secretary of state from 2009 to 2013. Questions have also surfaced again about her use of a private email server and address rather than a government one during her period at the State Department.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Trump and Clinton also sparred over who would be a better advocate for African Americans and other minorities
column3: and Trump hinted he could soften his hard-line stance on immigration. In a separate Reuters/Ipsos poll that includes candidates from small
column4: alternative parties
column5: Clinton leads the field by a smaller margin. Some 39 percent of likely voters supported Clinton in the four-way poll
column6: compared with 36 percent for Trump
column7: 7 percent for Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson and 3 percent for Green Party nominee Jill Stein.

column1: Both polls were conducted online in English in all 50 states. They included 1
column2: 154 likely voters and have a credibility interval of 3 percentage points.The results may differ from the Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project
column3: which includes a separate weekly tracking poll that measures support for the major party candidates in every state and Washington D.C.The States of the Nation
column4: released on Wednesday
column5: estimated that if the election were held now Clinton would have a 95 percent chance of winning by a margin of about 108 votes in the Electoral College
column6: the body that decides the election through a count of the candidates' wins in each state. (Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Frances Kerry)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-illinois-politics-idUSKCN1112HQ	Illinois governor urges 2018 vote on 'rigged' political mapmaking	"
By Dave McKinney
| CHICAGO

CHICAGO Illinois Republican Governor Bruce Rauner urged lawmakers on Friday to allow voters in 2018 to decide whether to change how political boundaries are drawn after the state's Supreme Court a day earlier declared a petition-driven redistricting initiative for this fall's statewide ballot unconstitutional.Rauner called Illinois' existing political maps
column2: which are drawn by Democrats who control the General Assembly
column3: ""rigged and gerrymandered"" because they have left a majority of legislative races this fall without challengers to incumbent legislators.""Our system of government is broken
column4: Rauner told reporters during a stop in Marion
column5: in far southern Illinois. ""Two-thirds of our general elections don't have opponents
column6: and we've got to change the system.""The next opportunity for state legislators to put a constitutional amendment before voters comes in two years
column7: when the first-term governor is expected to be in the midst of a re-election campaign.

column1: Our system has been run by a broken
column2: powerful political machine in Chicago that looks out for itself
column3: not for the people of Illinois
column4: and certainly not for the people of southern Illinois
column5: Rauner said. ""We've got to get the power away from that machine
column6: and we can do it with political reform.""Rauner's comments came less than 24 hours after the Illinois Supreme Court ruled 4-3 to uphold a lower court ruling that would keep in place the once-a-decade
column7: partisan-controlled political mapmaking process that has allowed for Democratic majorities in the state legislature and on the elected Supreme Court.

column1: The amendment
column2: if it was placed on November's ballot and passed by a majority of Illinois voters
column3: would have transferred the power of re-drawing legislative districts to a bipartisan commission. More than 563
column4: 000 Illinois voters signed petitions backing the amendment. There were 12 redistricting amendments filed in both chambers during the current legislative session though none won approval in both chambers.

column1: The Illinois Supreme Court ruled the ballot initiative fell outside the scope of permissible ballot initiatives
column2: which may only be used for amendments directed at ""structural and procedural subjects"" in the constitution pertaining to Illinois's legislative branch.In a dissenting opinion
column3: Justice Robert Thomas wrote: ""Today a muzzle has been placed on the people of this State
column4: and their voices supplanted by judicial fiat."" (Reporting by Dave McKinney in Chicago; Additional reporting by Kim Palmer in Cleveland
column5: Ohio
column6: and Eric M. Johnson in Seattle; Editing by Eric M. Johnson
column7: Bernard Orr)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-maine-lepage-idUSKCN1112CT	Maine governor apologizes for obscenity-laced voicemail	"
By Chris Prentice

Maine Governor Paul LePage apologized on Friday for an obscenity-laced voicemail he left for a lawmaker who he believed had called him a racist for remarks he made about drug dealers. The incident followed a town hall meeting on Wednesday during which LePage said he kept a binder with photographs of drug dealers arrested in Maine and more than 90 percent of them were black or Hispanic
column2: the Portland Press Herald reported. The governor's remarks triggered a barrage of criticism from political figures and the American Civil Liberties Union of Maine. LePage left the voicemail message for State Representative Drew Gattine after a television reporter said the lawmaker was among several people who had called the governor a racist.According to a recording of the message obtained by the Portland Press Herald
column3: LePage said in the message
column4: ""Mr. Gattine
column5: this is Gov. Paul Richard LePage. I would like to talk to you about your comments about my being a racist
column6: you cocksucker. I want to talk to you. I want you to prove that I'm a racist.  ""I've spent my life helping black people and you little son-of-a-bitch
column7: socialist cocksucker. You ... I need you to
column8: just friggin. I want you to record this and make it public because I am after you. Thank you.""

column1: The governor later told local reporters that he wished he could settle the dispute with Gattine by means of an armed duel.Gattine did not respond immediately to calls for comment.     He told the Press Herald that LePage's voicemail was ""uncalled for"" and that he never said the governor was a racist.An editorial in the Press Herald
column2: speaking for the state's voters
column3: said Maine apologized to America for electing
column4: then re-electing a ""governor who is unfit for high office.""

column1: After the voicemail became public
column2: LePage issued a statement apologizing to Maine citizens for calling Gattine ""the worst word [he] could think of"" in the voicemail.The governor defended his choice of language by saying the remarks were ""simply a metaphor"" that harkens back to the 1820s when political opponents ""used to call each other out.""""I meant no physical harm to Gattine
column3: LePage said in the statement.

column1: It is not the first time LePage has found himself the subject of controversy.Earlier this year
column2: he said that drug dealers ""come up here
column3: they sell their heroin and they go home. Incidentally
column4: half the time
column5: they impregnate a young white girl before they leave.""He later said the comment was a ""slip-up"" and that he meant to say that drug traffickers get ""young Maine girls"" pregnant and that most residents of Maine are white.Also in January
column6: LePage told Maine gun owners they should ""load up and get rid of the drug dealers.""  (Reporting by Chris Prentice; Editing by Andrew Hay)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-obama-legacy-race-idUSKCN11110Y	As racial politics loom over election
column2: Obama's legacy is seen as mixed	"

column1: By Jeff Mason
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON When Barack Obama became the first African-American to win the White House in 2008
column2: his victory was a turning point in U.S. race relations that set high expectations for progress to come.Nearly eight years later
column3: with Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton attacking each other over racial politics
column4: the legacy of Obama's presidency looks decidedly mixed
column5: black leaders said.To some
column6: the tone of the Republican presidential nominee's campaign
column7: as well as a recent series of racially charged shootings involving police
column8: show that the United States has come no closer to overcoming its history of racial strife.Having a black president
column9: two attorneys general and a chief of homeland security did not result in basic fairness for victims of racially charged violence
column11: an academic and former Obama supporter who has become a high-profile critic of the Democratic president. ""How many policemen who have murdered unarmed innocent black civilians have gone to jail with that kind of black power at the top? Zero
column12: West said.Obama could have acted more directly while in office to help blacks
column14: citing persistently high childhood poverty among African-Americans. ""The (economic) recovery has not filtered over into black and working poor communities
column15: he said.Others said Obama showed leadership on race while making real achievements on healthcare and the economy that helped Americans of all ethnicities.Al Sharpton
column16: a civil rights leader with close ties to the White House
column17: described Obama as a ""transformative"" president held back by the need to serve varying constituencies and compromise with lawmakers who had different priorities.""He tried to be as balanced and respectful as he could
column18: to the chagrin of many in the black community
column19: who felt that he was leaning over backwards

column1: Unemployment among African-Americans fell by half under Obama
column2: Sharpton noted
column3: while Obama's remarks on race elevated the issue. In 2012 at the White House
column4: Obama referred to Trayvon Martin
column5: a black youth gunned down by a white Hispanic man
column6: as a boy who would have resembled the son he did not have.""We've never had a president do that
column7: Sharpton said.FALSE SENSE OF PROGRESS

column1: Andrew Young
column2: a former Atlanta mayor
column3: congressman
column4: U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and adviser to slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King
column5: Jr.
column6: said Obama
column7: as a black leader
column8: had to seek compromise more than previous white presidents.""It was easier for (Jimmy) Carter or Lyndon Johnson
column9: even Bill Clinton as southern whites to do things specifically for black people
column10: Young said.Backlash from white working class voters had contributed to Trump's rise
column11: Young said.""We really haven't had a complete psychological adjustment to a multi-racial society
column12: he said. ""That's what's rallying people behind Trump. They're frustrated by the complexities of this day and age. And (Trump)
column14: gives a simple answer and blames it on somebody else.""Clinton
column16: blasted Trump on Thursday as a divisive candidate who was stoking racist groups. Trump criticized Clinton
column17: saying she had let black Americans down and was falsely labeling Republicans as bigoted.

column1: Clinton supporters were more likely to want to address race relations than Trump supporters
column2: a Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll of more than 2
column3: 800 people found in late March.Obama has said race relations are not as bad as some suggest. Friends say he never expected his presidency to wipe away centuries of racism and slavery's legacy.""To expect to erase all of that legacy of injustice or racism and discrimination in eight years is unrealistic
column4: said Valerie Jarrett
column5: a White House adviser and close Obama friend.""Were there people who probably had a false sense of progress based just on an election? Sure
column6: she said.The administration wants to advance criminal justice reform legislation before Obama leaves office
column7: aiming for a win on an issue watched closely in the black community. But prospects of passage in Congress during an election year are uncertain. Obama
column8: who has made clear his disdain for Trump and his frustration with Congress
column9: has said he hoped his own voice on race would help improve things for future generations. ""We plant seeds
column10: and somebody else maybe sits under the shade of the tree that we planted
column11: Obama said at a news conference in July. (Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-obama-idUSKCN1110BC	Obama's judges leave liberal imprint on U.S. law	"
By Lawrence Hurley
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON When President Barack Obama entered the White House in 2009
column2: the federal appeals court based in Virginia was known as one of the most conservative benches in the country.Two Obama terms later
column3: Democratic appointees hold a 10-5 majority on the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals
column4: a panel of which issued a groundbreaking ruling this April backing transgender rights.FACTBOX: Cases where Obama judges left a markThe shift to the left on the court
column5: which hears cases from Virginia
column6: Maryland
column7: West Virginia
column9: highlights a widely overlooked aspect of Obama's legacy.His appointments of dozens of judges to the country's influential federal appeals courts have tilted the judiciary in a liberal direction that will influence rulings for years to come and be further entrenched if Democrat Hillary Clinton wins this November's presidential election.MORE FROM REUTERSElection 2016 LIVE: Who is the better president for minority voters? Bolivia says deputy interior minister killed after kidnap by minersJudge orders search of Clinton emails from 2012 Benghazi attack by September 13A Reuters review of rulings by the courts over the last two years shows Obama's appointees to the appeals courts have influenced major legal battles likely to ultimately reach the Supreme Court.Obama-appointed judges have voted in favor of broad civil rights protections
column10: major Obama administration regulations and gun regulations and against Republican-backed voting rules.

column1: When seeking to appoint judges
column2: the White House has said it is looking for highly credentialed lawyers reflecting the diversity of U.S. society. Conservative critics say he has picked judges who are willing to circumvent the law in order to reach preferred outcomes.

column1: There's no question President Obama's nominees have absolutely been part of his effort to transform the country and move it dramatically to the left
column2: said Carrie Severino
column3: a conservative legal activist.White House spokesman Eric Schultz said in a statement that Obama's appointees ""all share impeccable qualifications
column4: unquestioned integrity
column5: and a steadfast commitment to equal justice under the law.""The appeals courts are the first stop for any case appealed from the lower U.S. district courts and often have the last word. The next and final destination is the Supreme Court
column6: but it hears fewer than 100 cases a year. The appeals courts handle 35
column7: 000 a year according to the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts.Of the 13 appeals courts
column8: nine now have a majority of Democratic appointees
column9: compared with one when Obama took office
column10: according to research carried out by Russell Wheeler
column11: a scholar at the Brookings Institution
column12: a Washington think tank.In addition to appointing two Supreme Court justices and dozens of district court judges
column13: Obama appointments now make up 55 of the current 168 appeals court judges
column14: according to the judiciary. Obama's current total of 323 district and appeals court appointments
column15: most of them district court judges
column16: is similar to the tallies achieved by other recent two-term presidents.The regional appeals courts are currently more powerful than ever because of the vacancy on the Supreme Court caused by the death of Justice Antonin Scalia
column17: which has left the court divided equally between liberals and conservatives. If the ideologically divided court splits 4-4
column18: the appeals court ruling is left intact. Such an outcome occurred four times in the Supreme Court term that recently ended.

column1: Scalia's seat is unlikely to be filled until next year due to political opposition from Republicans in the Senate
column2: which has the job of confirming nominees. COURTS TRANSFORMED

column1: One of the most dramatic transformations has been on the 4th Circuit.In July 2007
column2: 18 months before Obama became president
column3: Republican appointees held a 7-5 majority. Through a mix of seven Obama appointments and retirements
column4: Democratic appointees now hold sway.In April
column5: a three-judge panel featuring two Obama appointees ruled in favor of a transgender student seeking to use a boys' restroom. The two Obama appointees were in the majority
column6: with a Republican appointee dissenting.

column1: Three months later
column2: a three-judge panel featuring two Obama appointees and one judge appointed by Democratic President Bill Clinton struck down North Carolina's strict voter identification law on a 3-0 vote
column3: saying the state legislature had enacted it with discriminatory intent.It is one of several recent court rulings pushing back on Republican-led efforts to impose new voting regulations
column4: which Democrats say is intended to deter minorities from voting.Caroline Fredrickson
column5: president of liberal legal group the American Constitution Society
column6: said Republican-appointed judges are generally less likely to rule in favor of broad interpretations of civil rights. The transgender case would ""very likely"" have come out differently with a more conservative panel of judges
column7: she said.The federal appeals court in Washington
column8: D.C. is another where the balance of power has been flipped. Often known in legal circles as the second highest court in the land because it hears important cases concerning the federal government
column9: the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit was dominated by conservatives 6-3 when Obama took office.Obama was able to force through four appointments after a major showdown in the Senate. The court now has a 7-4 split in favor of Democratic appointees.In June
column12: cast the deciding vote as a three-judge panel upheld the Federal Communication Commission's so-called ""net neutrality"" regulation. Srinivasan joined a Clinton appointee in the majority. A judge appointed by Republican President Ronald Reagan dissented. The regulation is widely opposed by the telecommunications industry and backed by digital rights advocates.Obama's appointees do sometimes vote in favor of conservative outcomes. Paul Watford
column13: a judge on the San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals
column14: has on several occasions reached a different conclusion to his more liberal colleagues. In one recent decision from Aug. 15
column15: he dissented along with conservative judges when the court ruled that a death row inmate should be able to file a new appeal.When announcing three of his nominees to the appeals court in Washington at a White House press conference in June 2013
column16: Obama rejected any notion that they were political pawns
column17: emphasizing their strong credentials.""These are no slouches. These are no hacks
column18: he said. (Reporting by Lawrence Hurley; editing by Stuart Grudgings.)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-immigration-entrepreneurs-idUSKCN111242	White House proposes rule to welcome immigrant entrepreneurs	"
By Timothy Gardner
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The Obama administration proposed a rule on Friday aimed at attracting thousands of immigrant entrepreneurs to start companies in the United States. The rule
column2: proposed by the Department of Homeland Security
column3: would ease the ability of startup founders to build companies if they have significant funding from U.S. investors.The administration hopes the rule will be completed before President Barack Obama's term ends on Jan. 20.The proposed rule is part of Obama's commitment to ""attracting the world's best and brightest entrepreneurs to start the next great companies here
column4: Tom Kalil
column5: a technology policy adviser at the White House
column6: told reporters in a call.

column1: Kalil said immigrants have co-founded as many as one in four high-tech startups across the United States and more than half of all startups in Silicon Valley. Immigration has been a crucial issue in the 2016 presidential campaign ahead of the Nov. 8 election. Republican candidate Donald Trump has vowed to toughen immigration policies
column2: while Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton has proposed creating an office of immigrant affairs to expand Obama's efforts to help immigrants integrate better into the country.

column1: Under the rule
column2: DHS would issue temporary permission for entrepreneurs to live in the United States if they have at least 15 percent ownership in startup companies formed in the country within the past three years. The companies must have investment of at least $345
column3: 000 from qualified U.S. investors. The administration expects about 3
column4: 000 immigrants would apply for the temporary permission
column5: known as parole.Max Levchin
column6: a co-founder of PayPal and other companies who was born in Ukraine
column7: said the proposed rule is a ""great
column8: concrete step toward creating more jobs in America and more success stories.""

column1: Many entrepreneurs are educated at prestigious U.S. universities
column2: but find themselves unable to stay in the country  because they lose visa lotteries or can't afford to sponsor themselves through an existing investor visa program.""We lose and will continue to lose talented
column3: skilled
column4: well educated scientists
column5: engineers and entrepreneurs because they are simply not allowed to stay and work after we educated them to very high standards
column6: Levchin said. ""It makes very little sense."" (Reporting by Timothy Gardner; Editing by James Dalgleish)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-wolfowitz-idUSKCN1111XS	Former Bush adviser Wolfowitz to vote for Clinton: Spiegel	"
